Fig. 1 (a) Global minimum structures of Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19). (b) Eb,O and dPd-O correspond to the average adsorption strength of O and average bond length of Pd-O, respectively. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Average bond length and average coordination number of Pd-Pd (CNPd) as a function of nanocluster size. (Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19)). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The adsorption sites of adsorbates (H, H2, O2, OOH and H2O2) on all considered nanoclusters (Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19)) and surfaces (Pd(111), 0.16 ML and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111)). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Adsorption energies (Ead, eV) of adsorbates (H, O, OH, OOH, H2, O2, and H2O2) on all considered nanoclusters (Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19)) and surfaces (Pd(111), 0.16 ML and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111)). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Potential energy surface for the formation and decomposition of H2O2 on all considered nanoclusters (Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19)) and surfaces (Pd(111), 0.16 ML and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111)). The relative energy is given in eV. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Potential energy surface for the formation of H2O on all considered nanoclusters (Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19)) and surfaces (Pd(111), 0.16 ML and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111)). The relative energy is given in eV. Fig. 7 Theoretical study on the evolution of Pd catalysts and the effect on catalytic activity and selectivity during H2O2 direct synthesis Pan Li Conceptualization Software Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft a b Jingli Han Software Data curation Visualization c Zhongyi Liu Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ Yongpeng Yang Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration a b ⁎ a Green Catalysis Center, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China Green Catalysis Center College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 China aGreen Catalysis Center, College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, China b Henan Institute of Advanced Technology, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450003, China Henan Institute of Advanced Technology Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450003 China bHenan Institute of Advanced Technology, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450003, China c Henan Engineering Research Center of Catalysis and Separation of Cyclohexanol, School of Material and Chemical Engineering, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry, Zhengzhou 450001, China Henan Engineering Research Center of Catalysis and Separation of Cyclohexanol School of Material and Chemical Engineering Zhengzhou University of Light Industry Zhengzhou 450001 China cHenan Engineering Research Center of Catalysis and Separation of Cyclohexanol, School of Material and Chemical Engineering, Zhengzhou University of Light Industry, Zhengzhou 450001, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Pd catalysts show high activity and selectivity for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) direct synthesis. The catalytic performance is found to be strongly dependent on the catalyst size, and metallic Pd catalysts can be partially oxidized during reaction. To determine the active center of H2O2 direct synthesis, the catalytic activity of Pd with different oxidation degree was investigated in this study by using density functional theory. Firstly, the global minimum structures of Pdn, (PdO)n, and (PdO0.5)n (n = 4, 12, and 19) were obtained using minimum hopping method. It is found that the oxidation can induce significant structural reconstruction, which enhances the Pd-O interaction. The reaction paths of H2O2 and H2O formation were obtained, and then the rate coefficients were calculated to study the reactivity and selectivity. Pd(111) surfaces with different O coverage were also considered. After oxidized, the larger Pd nanoclusters and Pd(111) surface show higher reaction activity and H2O2 selectivity, due to the weakened O2 adsorption strength, increased energy barriers of H2O2 and OOH dissociation, and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111) shows superior catalytic activity and H2O2 selectivity. The partially oxidized Pd sites have high activity and selectivity for H2O2 formation. This work provides an insight into the evolution of Pd catalysts and the effect on catalytic performance during H2O2 direct synthesis. Graphical abstract H2O2 direct synthesis at Pd nanoclusters and Pd(111) surface with different oxidation degree. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd catalysts H2O2 direct synthesis Catalyst evolution Reaction path Rate coefficients Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is an efficient oxidizing agent because of its high active oxygen content, and it is used in many industries such as the bleaching of paper, detergents, medical industry, and the production of organic chemicals [1,2]. As reported [3], the consumption of hydrogen peroxide in the world is all through very large, and has been increasing rapidly. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is considered as a “green” oxidant in productions, because its by-product is only water [1,4]. The commercial production of H2O2 mainly depends on the anthraquinone auto-oxidation (AO) process, as well as electrolysis, isopropanol oxidation, and electrochemical cathode reduction of oxygen [5,6]. The AO process is a sophisticated method that needs extensive resources and generates waste, so it is unfriendly for environment, against sustainable development [7]. Not only that, the AO process has safety issues in transportation [4]. Thus, the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen catches the attention of chemists, which is simple to operate and low-polluting. And it has great potential to replace the AO method [8,9]. Pd-based (Pd or Pd alloy) catalysts are commonly known as effective catalysts in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide over the last few decades. Lunsford and co-workers [10–13] provided mechanistic investigation into the pathways for the reactions of H2 and O2 over colloidal palladium in an aqueous medium. Abate et al. studied Pd nanoparticles located on N-doped CNT and found they gave higher productivities to H2O2 than CNT [14]. In order to improve the selectivity of the Pd catalyst, some studies were performed to modify the palladium. Edwards et al. [15] prepared Au-Pd catalysts for the formation of H2O2 with high yields. Paunovic found that the activity of Pd-Au catalysts was dependent mostly on the Pd:Au ratio, and appropriate ratio resulted in a higher selectivity and productivity of H2O2 operating within the microreactor [16]. The direct synthesis of H2O2 on Pd(111) and Pd/Au catalysts was investigated with DFT by Staykov and they showed that Au atom blocked the dioxygen dissociation leading to the increase in the selectivity of H2O2 [17]. Besides Au, adding metallic platinum is also an alternative method. Melada et al. [18] used Pd-Pt tubular catalytic membranes to catalyze the direct synthesis of H2O2 and got higher productivity and selectivity. Pd-Pt/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts also promoted the direct synthesis of H2O2, which was studied by Liu [19]. As palladium catalysts continue to improve, the selectivity of H2O2 has been seen an increase. The researchers have explored the effect of size of the Pd catalysts and the valence states of the catalyst in the catalytic formation of H2O2. However, the view that the oxidized state of palladium which promotes the formation of H2O2 is still controversial nowadays. Huber et al. studied the adsorption sites of O2 on Pdn clusters (n = 1–4) and found the OO bond got stretched [20]. Sven et al. [21] researched the structural properties for a series of clusters Pdn (n = 4–309) and the effect of surface oxidation of Pd55O20. Liu et al. [22] demonstrated that Pd0 was the active phase for the formation of H2O2 rather than PdO in a H2SO4/ethanol system. Recently, the work of Agarwal et al. suggested that the Pd clusters was easily oxidized deeply than Au, and H2 could be used to reduce the oxidized metal [23]. Also, in previous studies, the oxidation state of palladium was discussed and argued that it could affect the catalytic performance in this reaction. Gaikwad and co-workers [24] proposed the PdO-containing Al2O3, ThO2, ZrO2, CeO2, Y2O3 and Ga2O3 were promising catalysts, which promoted the reaction of H2 to H2O2. In addition, Melada researched the direct synthesis of H2O2 on zirconia-supported catalysts, which showed surface-oxidized palladium is important for the reaction [25]. Choudhary et al. [26] considered that the PdO catalysts were active for the synthesis of H2O2 and appeared poor activity for the H2O2 decomposition. Comparing the presence or absence of halide or F− ions, Samanta et al. [27] got that Pd oxidation state had fairly strong effect on the selectivity of H2O2 when there was no halide or F− ions over Pd/Ga2O3. However, they found that Pd oxidation state was important for the synthesis of H2O2 in an aqueous containing F− and Cl− ions over Pd/Al2O3 [28]. Blanco et al. [29] concluded that the excellent performance of palladium-containing resins was due to the large quantities of Pd2+ ions interplaying with the -SO3H. Similarly, Pd2+ was observed that it existed on the surface in higher concentration, which resulted in the increase in activity [30]. Despite widely researching the direct synthesis of H2O2 on the Pd-based catalysts in experiments, it is not very clear in theoretical research. We focus on the size and oxidization state of the Pd catalysts effects in H2O2 synthesis using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Clusters including Pdn, (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19), (PdO0.5)n (n = 4, 12) and Pd19O10, simultaneously comparing with the extended surfaces Pd(111) and O/Pd(111) of the oxygen atoms coverage θ = 0.16 ML and θ = 0.32 ML. The aim of our study is to propose a mechanism of the direct synthesis of hydrogen and oxygen on the above clusters and surfaces. 2 Computational details All calculations were performed by using density functional theory (DFT) in the CP2K software package [31]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [32] was used as the exchange and correlation energy functional in the Gaussian and plane waves (GPW) [33] methods. The Goedecker-Tetter-Hutter (GTH) pseudopotentials [34] and DZVP-Molopt basis sets [35] were used for all atom species. The structures of all considered clusters were optimized by minimum hopping [36,37] in the CP2K code. Ab initio molecular dynamics [38] was used to prove the stability of these nanoclusters at 500 K, as shown in Figs. S1-S9. The cutoff of plane-wave density is set to be 400 Ry, and the self-consistent field tolerance was 1 × 1 0 − 6 Ha. The size of periodic cubic simulation box is different for all considered clusters, Pd4 (16×16×16 Å), Pd4O2 and Pd4O4 (18×18×18 Å), Pd12, Pd12O6, and Pd12O12 (20×20×20 Å), Pd19 (22×22×22 Å), Pd19O10 and Pd19O19 (24×24×24 Å). For the surfaces, a 5 × 5 unit cells with four-layer thick metal slabs was calculated, with 10 Å vacuum. The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [39] was used to compute the transition state and reaction barrier with the convergence criterion of maximum force on the band 2 × 1 0 − 3 Ha per Bohr. The mechanism of the direct synthesis of H2O2 is considered as a two-step hydrogenation, and the intermediate OOH is produced by hydrogenation of O2 [40]. We also considered the decomposition of H2O2 and the non-selective formation of H2O. All the detailed elementary steps are showed in Eqs. (1)-(11). (1) H 2 ( g ) ↔ H 2 * (2) O 2 ( g ) ↔ O 2 * (3) H 2 * + * ↔ 2 H * (4) H * + O 2 * ↔ OO H * (5) H * + OO H * ↔ H 2 O 2 * (6) H 2 O 2 * ↔ H 2 O 2 ( g ) (7) H 2 O 2 * ↔ 2 O H * (8) OO H * ↔ O H * + O * (9) O 2 * ↔ 2 O * (10) H * + O * ↔ O H * (11) H * + O H * ↔ H 2 O ( g ) The adsorption energies (Ead) were calculated as: (12) E ad = E adsorbate / catalyst − E catalyst − E adsorbate where Eadsorbate/catalyst, Ecatalyst, and Eadsorbate represent the total energies of the catalyst with the adsorbate, the clusters or surfaces, and the adsorbate species in the gas phase, respectively. The reaction energies (∆E) and activation barriers (Ea) of each elementary step were calculated as: (13) Δ E = E FS − E IS (14) E a = E TS − E IS where EIS, ETS and EFS are the total energies of the initial state, transition state and final state, respectively. The kinetic properties were calculated by using the partial Hessian vibrational analysis (PHVA) method as implemented in TAMkin-toolkit [41] at 300 K and 400 K. The rate coefficients were determined from transition-state theory (TST) as following: (15) k = k B T h q TS q RS exp ( − Δ E 0 ‡ k B T ) where k B is the Boltzmann constant, h is the Plank constant, q RS and q TS relate to the partial functions of reactants and transition states, respectively, and Δ E 0 ‡ is the reaction barrier including zero-point energy correction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometric structure of Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19) clusters The global minimum structures of Pdn, (PdO0.5)n and (PdO)n (n = 4, 12 and 19) are displayed in Fig. 1 , and the average bond length (dPd-Pd) and average coordination number (CNPd) of Pd-Pd are summarized in Fig. 2 . Pd4 is a regular tetrahedral cluster, which coincides with previous report [21,42]. and the dPd-Pd is 2.62 Å. Pd12 has D2d symmetry, and the dPd-Pd increases to 2.73 Å. However, the dPd-Pd of Pd19 slightly decreases to 2.72 Å, which is due to the high symmetry (Oh). When Pd nanoclusters partially oxidized to form (PdO0.5)n, their structures change significantly. The symmetry of Pd4O2 is Cs, and it is composed of tetrahedral Pd frame and two bridge oxygen atoms. Pd12O6 also has Cs symmetry with a neutral Pd atom in the core and surface, respectively. Four of the oxygen atoms are adsorbed at hollow site, and the others are adsorbed at bridge site. For Pd19O10, there are two neutral Pd atoms in the core and surface, respectively, and all the oxygen atoms are adsorbed at hollow site. It is found that the average adsorption energy of oxygen of Pd19O10 is larger than those of Pd4O2 and Pd12O6, although the ratio of Pd:O is same. This can be ascribed to that oxygen atoms prefer to be adsorbed at hollow sites, and all the oxygen in Pd19O10 are hollow atoms. With the Pd nanoclusters further oxidized to form (PdO)n, Pd4O4 transforms into a planar nanocluster with D2h symmetry. For Pd12O12, there is still one neutral Pd atom in the core and all O atoms are adsorbed at hollow site except for two bridge O atoms. Similarly, all the surface Pd atoms bind with oxygen with two neutral Pd atoms in the core of Pd19O19. The average adsorption energy of oxygen of Pd19O19 (−1.18 eV) is smaller than those of Pd4O4 (−1.19 eV) and Pd12O12 (−1.20 eV), although Pd19O10 has the largest value among (PdO0.5)n nanoclusters, suggesting that the larger Pd nanoclusters are more difficult to be highly oxidized. Meanwhile, the average Pd-Pd distance increases, and the average Pd-Pd coordination number decreases with the degree of oxidation increasing, as shown in Fig. 2. 3.2 Adsorption properties of adsorbates on Pd and PdOx The adsorption properties of intermediates during H2O2 direct synthesis are investigated, including H2, O2, H, O, OH, OOH and H2O2. Not only the Pd1Ox (x = 0, 0.5 and 1) nanoclusters but also Pd(111) surface with different O coverages are taken into account, in the light of previous report that Pd(111) surface exhibits the highest catalytic selectivity for H2O2 among Pd(111), Pd(110) and Pd(100) [43]. The oxygen atoms prefer to be adsorbed at fcc site of Pd(111) in our work, which coincides with previous results [44], and two oxygen coverages 0.16 ML and 0.32 ML are considered. The adsorption sites of the major adsorbates (H, H2, O2, OOH and H2O2) are summarized in Fig. 3 and adsorption energies of these adsorbates are displayed in Fig. 4 . H2 molecule prefers to be adsorbed at one Pd atom to form Kubas bond on all the Pd nanoclusters and surfaces. The H2 adsorption on Pd nanoclusters is stronger than on Pd surfaces, and it decreases with Pd gradually oxidized. It should be pointed out that the H2 adsorption energies are slightly increased when Pd12 and Pd19 are oxidized into (PdO)12 and (PdO)19, compared with corresponding metallic Pd nanoclusters. Similar trend is also found for the H adsorption, and the adsorption is endothermic on Pd4O4. O2 molecule prefers to be adsorbed at two atop sites of metallic Pd nanoclusters, and the Pd nanoclusters have stronger O2 bind strength than Pd(111) surface, where O2 is adsorbed at two atop and bridge sites. When metallic Pd oxidized into PdO0.5, the O2 adsorption energy decreases, but it significantly increases from −1.14 eV to −2.01 eV. Besides, they are increased by 0.35 eV for (PdO)12 and 0.14 eV for (PdO)19, respectively, compared with corresponding (PdO0.5)n nanoclusters, and the favorable O2 adsorption changes into two atop and bridge sites on (PdO)12. The adsorption of O2 is stronger than that of H2 among all the considered Pd catalysts, except for Pd4O4. For the Pd(111) surface, the adsorption energies of O2 and H2 both monotonously decrease with the Pd oxidation. But they can be strengthened when the PdO0.5 further oxidized into (PdO)12 and (PdO)19. This fact can be ascribed to the reconstruction of Pd nanoclusters, which has been also found in our previous study of CO adsorption on AunCOm nanoclusters [45]. The adsorption properties of H2O2 are also strongly dependent on the size and oxidation degree of Pd nanoclusters. For the metallic Pd nanoclusters, H2O2 prefers to be adsorbed at one atop site with O atom, and the adsorption energies of H2O2 vary from −0.42 eV to −0.60 eV. The hydrogen bond between H2O2 and Pd oxidates significantly strengthens their interaction. For example, the H2O2 adsorption energies on Pd19O10 and Pd19O19 increase from −0.57 eV (Pd19) to −0.78 eV and −1.27 eV, respectively. Meanwhile, the hydrogen bond dominates the interaction between H2O2 and Pd4O4, and Pd-O interaction is weak in the light of much longer Pd-O bond length. H, O, OH and OOH are the key intermediates for H2O2 synthesis, and their adsorption properties are shown in Fig. 3. It was found that the adsorption energy of H decreases with the oxidation degree of Pd nanoclusters increasing. On the contrary, the adsorption of O, OH and OOH can be strengthened due to the structural reconstruction induced by oxidation. Because no considerable reconstruction was found for the Pd(111), the adsorption strength of all the adsorbates is weakened with the increase of O coverages. 3.3 Direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 3.3.1 Direct formation of H2O2 on metallic Pd The reaction paths of H2O2 formation on Pd nanoclusters and Pd(111) surface are shown in Fig. 5 . It is found that the dissociation energy barrier of H2 decreases from 0.41 eV on Pd4 to 0.16 eV on Pd(111) surface with the Pd nanocluster size increasing. It was proved that the H2 consumption rate correlated with the size of Pd particles, and the catalytic activity increased with the surface area of the Pd particles [46]. For all the metallic Pd nanoclusters and Pd(111) surface, the rate-determining step of H2O2 formation is the first hydrogenation of O2, where the energy barrier is 0.99 eV, 1.54 eV, 1.05 eV and 0.60 eV, respectively, with size increasing. Meanwhile, the reaction of H and OOH undergoes an energy barrier of 0.84 eV, 1.12 eV, 0.97 eV, and 0.55 eV, respectively. The dissociation barriers of O2 are 1.57 eV (Pd12), 1.05 eV (Pd19), 0.58 eV (Pd(111)), which are very close to those of the first hydrogenation of O2, except for Pd4, where the O2 dissociation barrier increases by 0.32 eV, as showed in Fig. 6 . The OOH can easily dissociate into O and OH with overcoming very small barrier on Pd12 (0.03 eV), and Pd(111) (0.07 eV), although it is higher on Pd4 (0.40 eV) and Pd19 (0.20 eV). Similarly, there is also a clear tendency for H2O2 dissociation, where the barrier varies from 0.03 eV to 0.25 eV and is much smaller than the desorption energy of H2O2. As by-product of H2O2 direct synthesis, H2O is formed by the reaction between OH and H with overcoming an energy barrier of 0.80 eV (Pd4), 1.55 eV (Pd12), 1.13 eV (Pd19), and 0.87 eV (Pd(111)), which is higher than that of the reaction of O and H, except for Pd(111). By comparing the energy barriers of O2 dissociation, first hydrogenation of O2 and OOH dissociation, the O is mainly produced by the OOH dissociation on Pd4, and both of the O2 and OOH dissociation are the source of O on Pd12, Pd19 and Pd(111). 3.3.2 The effect of oxidation of Pd on H2O2 formation Then the effect of oxidation on the direct synthesis of H2O2 is discussed in this section. For Pd4O2, the energy barrier of H2 dissociation and the first hydrogenation of O2 is decreased by 0.15 eV and 0.12 eV, respectively, compared with Pd4. However, it is increased by 0.97 eV for the hydrogenation of OOH, which is the rate-determining step of H2O2 formation. Meanwhile, the OOH and H2O2 dissociation are hindered with the increased energy barriers of 0.60 eV and 0.46 eV, respectively. These changes of reaction energy barriers are similar for Pd12O6, except for the increased H2 dissociation barrier by 0.19 eV. For Pd12O12, the barriers of H2 and O2 dissociation significantly increase by 0.55 eV and 0.93 eV, respectively, compared with Pd12O6. The first hydrogenation of O2 is the rate-determining step of H2O2 formation with an energy barrier of 1.11 eV, and the dissociation barrier of H2O2 and OOH decrease to 0.02 eV and 0.21 eV, respectively. Compared with Pd19, the energy barrier of the hydrogenation of O2 and OOH decreases to 0.49 eV and 0.72 eV on Pd19O10. The dissociation energy barrier of O2 and H2O2 increases to 1.37 eV and 0.27 eV. However, for Pd19O19, the barrier of H2 and O2 dissociation significantly increases to 1.13 eV and 2.07 eV, respectively. Meanwhile, the barrier of the hydrogenation of O2 and OOH increases to 0.99 eV and 1.16 eV, and it decreases to 0.08 eV for the H2O2 dissociation. When O coverage reaches 0.16 ML for Pd(111) surface, the barrier of H2 dissociation slightly decreases to 0.12 eV, and the barrier of the hydrogenation of OOH decreases by 0.09 eV. The dissociation of O2, OOH and H2O2 are hindered with the increased energy barriers by 0.17 eV, 0.23 eV and 0.02 eV. With the O coverage further increasing to 0.32 ML, the barrier of H2 and O2 dissociation significantly increases to 0.70 eV and 2.04 eV, respectively. The increased O coverage has negligible effect on the first hydrogen of O2, where the energy barrier remains to be 0.60 eV. But it increases to 0.66 eV and 0.53 eV for the hydrogenation of OOH and H2O2 dissociation. By comparing the reaction paths of H2O2 direct synthesis on the Pd catalysts, not only the O2 dissociation but also other reactions, such as H2, H2O2 and OOH dissociation, strongly depend on the oxidation degree [47–50]. For small Pd nanoclusters (Pd4 and Pd12), the low degree of oxidation can decrease the energy barrier of O2 dissociation due to the geometric reconstruction. The energy barrier of the first hydrogenation of O2 decreases, but it is increased for the OOH hydrogenation. Besides, the dissociation of OOH and H2O2 is suppressed, which is similar to Pd19 and Pd(111). On the contrary, the low degree of oxidation slightly suppresses the O2 dissociation and accelerates the hydrogenation of OOH for Pd19 and Pd(111). When the oxidation degree is increased, the H2 dissociation, as well as O2 dissociation, is significantly hindered for all the Pd catalysts. In previous reports [51–53], it has been proved that oxidized Pd catalysts could reduce the dissociative activation of O2 and H2O2. It should be pointed out that although the H2O2 dissociation barrier is increased at high oxidation degree, the H2O2 adsorption is also strengthened. 3.4 Reaction coefficients The rate coefficients of the H2O2 and H2O formation at 300 K and 400 K are shown in Fig. 7 . For the first hydrogenation of O2 on metallic Pd catalysts, the rate coefficients increase monotonically with size increasing, except that Pd4 shows close value with Pd19. After Pd nanoclusters oxidized into (PdO)n, the rate coefficients significantly increase except for Pd(111) surface, and it decreases with nanoclusters further oxidized. Pd19O10 exhibits the largest rate coefficient of O2 hydrogenation among all the considered Pd catalysts. The trend of rate coefficients of OOH hydrogenation is similar to that of O2 hydrogenation. It is noted that Pd(111) with 0.16 ML O coverage shows the largest rate coefficient of OOH hydrogenation. For the metallic Pd catalysts, the reaction rate coefficient of O2 dissociation follow the order: Pd(111) > Pd19 > Pd4 > Pd12, and it decreases with gradually oxidized. It should be pointed out that the rate coefficients of O2 dissociation are smaller than those of O2 hydrogenation on the considered Pd catalysts with or without oxidized, except for metallic Pd12 and Pd19 nanoclusters. Thus, O2 prefers to hydrogenate rather than dissociate. The rate coefficient of OOH dissociation on the metallic Pd catalysts are very high, and it is largest on Pd(111), which is six orders of magnitude higher than that of OOH hydrogenation on Pd(111). The oxidation still can decrease the rate coefficient of OOH dissociation, especially for Pd19O19 and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111), and it is smaller than that of OOH hydrogenation only on the 0.32 ML O/Pd(111). Similarly, the rate coefficients of H2O2 decomposition are still very high, and they decrease with size increasing (Fig. 7d). The 0.32 ML O/Pd(111) exhibits the smallest rate coefficients of H2O2 decomposition. Thus, the 0.32 ML O/Pd(111) shows the highest H2O2 select, and the reaction activity is also remarkable in the light of reaction rate coefficients. It should be emphasized the H2O formation mainly depends on the route of OOH and H2O2 dissociation instead of O2 dissociation because of the much higher rate coefficients of the former, and the O2 hydrogenation is also faster than its dissociation. When the temperature rises from 300 K to 400 K, all the reaction rate coefficients increase as shown in Fig. 7 below the dotted line. The O2 dissociation rate coefficients are found to be increased by around 2∼6 orders of magnitude on Pdn, (PdO0.5)n, Pd(111) and 0.16 ML O/Pd(111), and the increased degree is even more significant on (PdO)n and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111) with over 8 orders of magnitude [54,55]. But for O2 hydrogenation, the increased degree is mainly within 3 orders of magnitude, which is not as significant as that of O2 dissociation. For example, the increased degree for O2 hydrogenation is 2.2, 2.3 and 2.4 orders of magnitude on Pd(111), 0.16 ML O/Pd(111) and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111), respectively, which is smaller by 0.1, 0.7, 6.1 orders of magnitude, compared with the O2 dissociation. The significantly enhanced O2 dissociation is not beneficial for increasing H2O2 selectivity. On the other hand, the increased degree of OOH hydrogenation is more remarkable than that of OOH dissociation, except for on 0.32 ML O/Pd(111), where the increased degree of OOH dissociation is higher by 0.3 orders of magnitude. Meanwhile, the H2O2 dissociation is less sensitivity to temperature. 3.5 The activity and selectivity of H2O2 The size and the extent of oxidation both impact the activity and selectivity to H2O2. Compared with metallic Pd clusters, the energy barriers of OOH formation on oxidized clusters are lower. Especially for Pd19 clusters, the value is 0.49 eV on Pd19O10 and decreases by 0.56 eV than metallic Pd cluster. We found that the OOH formation barrier increased when the valence changed from +1 to +2. However, the extent of oxidation has little effect on OOH formation barrier for the surface Pd(111). After oxidizing, the O2 and OOH decomposition barrier increased significantly on both nanoclusters and surface, which promotes the formation of H2O2. The energy barrier of H2O2 formation is 0.84 eV, 1.81 eV, 1.12 eV and 1.23 eV on Pd4, Pd4O2, Pd12 and Pd12O6, respectively. It demonstrates that Pd+ is not conducive to H2O2 formation, when the nanoclusters are small. For lager nanoclusters, Pd19O10 has lower energy barrier of H2O2 formation than metallic Pd19 and Pd19O19. And the H2O2 decomposition barrier on Pd19O10 is higher. So, Pd19O10 plays a positive role to H2O2 formation. Although the H2O2 formation barrier on 0.32 ML O/Pd(111) is higher than Pd(111) and 0.16 ML O/Pd(111), the H2O2 decomposition is much higher, 0.53 eV. Also, the energy barrier of O2 decomposition is 2.04 eV, 2.72 times higher than that on 0.16 ML O/Pd(111). That is beneficial to OOH and H2O2 formation, which is compatible with the rate coefficients calculated. In conclusion, 0.32 ML O/Pd(111) has the better catalytic activity and H2O2 selectivity among these catalysts. 4 Conclusions The reaction mechanisms of H2O2 direct synthesis on Pdn, (PdO)n, (PdO0.5)n (n = 4, 12, and 19) and Pd(111) surface with different O coverages are studied. Firstly, the global minimum structures of Pdn, (PdO)n, and (PdO0.5)n (n = 4, 12, and 19) were obtained using minimum hopping method. It is found that the adsorption energy of H decreases with the oxidation degree of Pd nanoclusters increasing. On the contrary, the adsorption of O, OH and OOH can be strengthened due to the structural reconstruction induced by oxidation. Because no considerable reconstruction was found for the Pd(111), the adsorption strength of all the adsorbates is weakened with the increase of O coverages. The rate-determining step for H2O2 formation is the first hydrogenation of O2 on the metallic Pd catalysts, but it changes into the hydrogenation of OOH after oxidized. The energy barrier of O2 dissociation is increased with the oxidation degree increasing. The high oxidation degree of Pd nanoclusters enhances the H2O2 adsorption due to the formation of hydrogen bond between H2O2 and surface O, which hinders the H2O2 desorption and accelerate its dissociation. According to the rate coefficients at 300 K and 400 K, The H2O formation is found to be dominated by the OOH and H2O2 dissociation instead of O2 dissociation. The higher temperature decreases the H2O2 selectivity due to the more significantly enhanced O2 and OOH dissociation, and the H2O2 dissociation is less sensitivity to temperature. In short, the partially oxidized Pd sites are beneficial for H2O2 formation. coredata.dc:description: Pd catalysts show high activity and selectivity for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) direct synthesis. The catalytic performance is found to be strongly dependent on the catalyst size, and metallic Pd catalysts can be partially oxidized during reaction. To determine the active center of H2O2 direct synthesis, the catalytic activity of Pd with different oxidation degree was investigated in this study by using density functional theory. Firstly, the global minimum structures of Pdn, (PdO)n, and (PdO0.5)n (n = 4, 12, and 19) were obtained using minimum hopping method. It is found that the oxidation can induce significant structural reconstruction, which enhances the Pd-O interaction. The reaction paths of H2O2 and H2O formation were obtained, and then the rate coefficients were calculated to study the reactivity and selectivity. Pd(111) surfaces with different O coverage were also considered. After oxidized, the larger Pd nanoclusters and Pd(111) surface show higher reaction activity and H2O2 selectivity, due to the weakened O2 adsorption strength, increased energy barriers of H2O2 and OOH dissociation, and 0.32 ML O/Pd(111) shows superior catalytic activity and H2O2 selectivity. The partially oxidized Pd sites have high activity and selectivity for H2O2 formation. This work provides an insight into the evolution of Pd catalysts and the effect on catalytic performance during H2O2 direct synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical study on the evolution of Pd catalysts and the effect on catalytic activity and selectivity during H2O2 direct synthesis
